awd_abstract_narration:
The Departments of Mathematics and Aerospace Science Engineering at Tuskegee University will jointly develop and implement "Strategies for Effective Engagement (SEE)". This project will address the challenges of academic achievement and retention of students enrolled in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) entry-level courses. Factors such as under-preparation in math, being first generation college students, social challenges, and an unfamiliar environment away from home have a negative effect on student motivation, performance, and retention. The SEE project will address these issues and enhance the students' learning and academic success by implementing a flipped learning environment, integrating technology with instruction, and implementing structured mentoring in the entry level math and engineering courses. This serves the national interest by educating students for the technical and scientific workforce.  

The main objective of SEE is to enhance students' self-efficacy, engagement, and motivation by integrating active teaching strategies and techniques. The flipped classroom will allow professors to use face-to-face class time more effectively and engage students in hands-on active learning opportunities. Innovative teaching methods that utilize technology and real-world problem solving will be implemented. The classroom interactions will be supported by math and engineering software. A consultant, whose expertise is in instructional design and authentic assessments, will support the project team. Formative and summative assessments of the pedagogical approach will be carried out through validated instruments of motivation and self-regulated learning. The intellectual merit of the project will address how active instruction that spans the disciplines of math and engineering can foster deep and conceptual learning in a meaningful context.

por.por_cntn:
Strategies for Effective Engagement (SEE)


The low interest and graduation rates in STEM, especially of underrepresented groups was the impetus for the "Strategies for Effective Engagement (SEE)" project funded by the NSF IUSE program. The project team developed and implemented strategies at Tuskegee University, an HBCU, to engage undergraduate STEM students cognitively, affectively, and behaviorally. These strategies focused on engagement both inside and outside the classroom to strengthen the learning outcomes and develop positive attitudes in the students towards STEM. Information technology resources were fully leveraged in developing the strategies. Peer-to-peer interactions, communication skills, and real-life problem solving for developing critical thinking skills were integral part of the methodology.

 

The SEE approach was implemented in eight lower-level math and aerospace engineering courses: Pre-Calculus Algebra (Math 107), Pre-Calculus Trigonometry (Math 108), Pre-Calculus Algebra and Trigonometry (Math 110), Calculus I (Math 207), Introduction to Aerospace Engineering (AENG 100), Introduction to Aerospace Engineering Lab (AENG 200), Aerospace Structures I (AENG 242), and Aerodynamics I (AENG 244).

 

The strategies developed and implemented under the project resulted in a positive impact on student learning. The final grades data (Fig. 1) indicates that not only the number of failures was reduced in the various courses where the SEE approach was implemented but also the number of higher grades achieved by the students was increased.

A validated instrument was used to measure the effectiveness of the approach and its impact on students' attitudes towards STEM subjects. This instrument measures five dimensions which are self-efficacy, intrinsic value, test anxiety, cognitive strategy use, and self-regulation.

A total of 271 math students and a total of 121 aerospace engineering students participated in the research study over the three years duration of the project. The responses of the students to the survey instrument were recorded at the start of a course (pretest) and then at the end of the course (posttest). The responses were averaged for each of the five dimensions. Positive changes were observed in each of the measured dimensions in both math and aerospace courses as seen in Figures 2 and 3. 

The responses were also averaged for each of the five dimensions based on the gender of the respondents. There were 172 female and 99 male respondents in the math courses, and 27 female and 102 male respondents in the aerospace engineering courses. These averages are shown in Figures 4 and 5. For math courses, male students had higher averages of the posttest responses than female students in all dimensions (Fig. 3). While for the aerospace engineering courses, the averages of the posttest responses of the males were only slightly larger than the females except for self-efficacy dimension where the male students had a larger posttest average.

Based on the research results (Figures 2, 3, 4, 5), the SEE project had a positive impact on the attitudes of the participating students in both math and aerospace engineering courses. The data revealed only slight posttest differences between female and male students indicating that the approach is equally effective for both.

Several professional development workshops for faculty at Tuskegee University were also conducted to share the SEE strategies and best practices for implementation.

A manual with best practices describing the SEE project strategies that promote cognitive engagement was developed. A website for the SEE project was also developed.

The research results of the SEE project have been disseminated at various professional conferences.

a)    Publish in peer-reviewed conference proceedings/journals

1. Aji, C. A. and Khan, M. J. (2021), Strategies for Effective Engagement and Learning in the COVID-19 Environment, Proc. 2021 ASEE Annual Conference, July 26 - 29, 2021
https://peer.asee.org/strategies-for-effective-engagement-and-learning-in-the-covid-19-environment

2. Aji, C. A. and Khan, M. J. (2020). Innovative Learning Strategies to Engage Students Cognitively. Proc. 2020 ASEE Virtual Annual Conference
https://peer.asee.org/innovative-learning-strategies-to-engage-students-cognitively

3. Aji, C. A. and Khan, M. J. (2020), Effective Instructional Strategies for Deeper Learning Paper presented at 2020 Gulf Southwest Section Conference, April 23-29, 2020
file:///Users/chadiaaffaneaji/Downloads/effective-instructional-strategies-for-deeper-learning%20(2).pdf

4. Aji, C. A. and Khan, M. J. (2019). The Impact of Active Learning on Students? Academic Performance. Open Journal of Social Sciences, 2019, 7, 204-211
https://www.researchgate.net/publication/331681258_The_Impact_of_Active_Learning_on_Students'_Academic_Performance

5. Aji, C. A. and Khan, M. J. (2019). Flipped Classroom and its Impact on Student Engagement. Proc. 126th ASEE Annual Conference and Exposition, June 16-19, 2019, Tampa FL
https://peer.asee.org/flipped-classroom-and-its-impact-on-student-engagement

b)    Presentations at professional conferences

1.     CUR Annual Meeting 2018

2.     8th International Conference on Information Technology in Education, 2019

3.     IICE Hawaii 2019, Jan 3 - 5, 2019, Honolulu, HI

4.     ASEE GSW Conference 2019

5.     ASEE Annual Meeting 2019

6.     HBCU FDN Conference, 2019

7.     ASEE GSW Conference, 2020

8.     ASEE Annual Conference, 2020

9.     ASEE Annual Conference, 2021

 

c)     SEE project website: https://www.tu-strategies-for-effective-engagement.org/


 


Last Modified: 10/31/2021
Modified by: Chadia Affane Aji
